docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, it was an article of medical faith: Get a mammogram; it could save your life. Now, seemingly overnight, that faith has been shaken. The mammogram -- that yearly ritual for millions of American women -- has become the focus of a bitter and unusually public scientific dispute that is being fought in the pages of medical journals and the columns of daily newspapers. Scientists, policy makers and politicians have scheduled meetings and Congressional hearings.

headline.main: X-Ray Vision in Hindsight: Science, Politics and the Mammogram

docs.abstract: Mammogram, yearly ritual for millions of American women, has become focus of bitter and unusually public scientific dispute that is being fought in pages of medical journals and columns of daily newspapers; how dispute came to be is story of science and politics and business of medicine, and war on cancer that seized on mammography as central weapon; it is also story of way science struggles toward ever evolving 'truth'; detailed accounting of controversy over mammograms; chronology of changing advice on test; graph; photos (L)

byline.original: By GINA KOLATA and MICHAEL MOSS

docs.lead_paragraph: Top executives of Enron, many of whom left the company with millions, have not opened their wallets to help their former employees pay their rent or rebuild their retirement funds. But for short-term relief, the employees can still thank the company's largess -- at least, its political largess. The bulk of the money feeding charitable funds for former Enron employees has come from politicians anxious to purge themselves of what Mary Matalin, the counselor to Vice President Dick Cheney, termed ''guilt by contribution,'' or who simply feel that it is appropriate to return donations from people who have fallen on hard times.

headline.main: Some Politicians Give Away Contributions From Enron

docs.abstract: Bulk of money contributed to charitable funds that are helping former Enron employees has come from politicians who are either anxious to purge themselves of guilt for accepting contributions or simply feel it is appropriate to return donations from people who have fallen on hard times; some political contributions noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Good Bill, Bad Politics'' (editorial, Feb. 8) charges the New York State Assembly with stalling on critical, long-overdue women's health legislation. This is unfair to the members of the Assembly's Democratic conference, who for four years have fought to provide access to vital women's health care services. Arguing for the inclusion of mammograms, Pap smears and contraceptive services is not trivial.

headline.main: Why a Women's Health Bill Is Mired in Albany

docs.abstract: New York State Assembly members Sheldon Silver and Deborah Glick letter on Feb 8 editorial denies Assembly stalls women's health bill for political reasons

docs.lead_paragraph: Sitting in her West 135th Street apartment, Marina Aguilera held a cup of hot tea in one hand and a small blue and red packet of tablets in the other. She calls the tablets ''la combinación,'' and she takes them for just about everything. ''This is good for earaches, for sore throats, chest pains, bad colds,'' said Ms. Aguilera, a 40-year-old mother of five. ''I don't know if it helps with the headaches. I don't think so.''

headline.main: At the Bodega, Antibiotics With No Prescription Needed

docs.abstract: Article on availability of Ampitrex, ampicillin which is made in Dominican Republic by Feltrex Laboratories, smuggled into Manhattan's Washington Heights neighborhood and sold, without prescription, at local bodegas; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JOHN H. PARK, who runs the $100 million Liberty Acorn Twenty fund, isn't overly concerned about labels like growth and value. ''We'll buy whatever's out of favor,'' Mr. Parks said from his office in downtown Chicago. ''We tend to shift between growth and value stocks depending on where they are in the cycle.''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I have enough saved to produce an adequate retirement income, and if I didn't thoroughly enjoy my job I would give serious thought to cutting back. But between my husband's and my prescription medicines, we can't afford to let go of the medical coverage.

headline.main: Working Until 70, If Work Is Available

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Arnold Schwarzenegger revenge picture ''Collateral Damage,'' which opened on Friday, had its original release date in November postponed when Warner Brothers executives speculated that the sight of the hero's wife and young son being blown up by terrorists would be in poor taste. That it would be in poor taste at any other time probably hadn't occurred to them -- and why should it have? ''Gladiator,'' which offered the spectacle of the hero's young son flattened by a chariot and strung up alongside his mother, was honored by Hollywood as the best picture of 2000. The same year, the hero of ''The Patriot'' wrapped himself in the American flag to impale or scalp the murderous Englishmen who had shot his unarmed young son.

headline.main: Vigilante Vengeance, Hollywood's Response To Primal Fantasies

docs.abstract: David Edelstein article traces history of Hollywood's vigilante-based movies, popular long before terrorist attacks; notes vigilantism, once almost exclusive province of white males, has become accessible to African-Americans; focuses on Arnold Schwarzenegger's latest picture Collateral Damage, John Q, starring Denzel Washington, and In the Bedroom, starring Tom Wilkinson; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THRILLERS blending business dealings and derring-do form a genre in their own right, and ''The Day Trader,'' by Stephen W. Frey (Ballantine Publishing Group, $24.95), fits admirably into this high-octane niche. It is a tale of market misdeeds and murder with characters ranging from traders shorting stocks to table dancers dealing in quite different commodities. But there's a problem: after the bull market days that seem to have inspired the book -- and that certainly inspired many day traders to gamble their life savings on magical stock valuations -- fact has become stranger than any fiction.

headline.main: A Lurid Tale, Overtaken by Events

docs.abstract: Alan Cowell reviews book The Day Trader by Stephen W Frey; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: OVER the past century medicine has wrought so many miracles that progress has come to seem inexorable. A discovery is made, a cure is found. Next, please. But the truth is that medical science, like all science, does not proceed from ignorance to enlightenment in a straight line. Indeed, it is more accurately described, in the words of the philosopher Miquel de Unamuno, as ''a cemetery of dead ideas,'' with one seeming truth being thrown out for another that fits better with the latest research.

headline.main: The Nation: Second Opinion; The Painful Fact of Medical Uncertainty

docs.abstract: Debate over role of mammography in early detection of breast cancer discussed; photo (M)
